Class MyGame

java.lang.Object
MyGame.MyGame
public final class MyGame extends Object

A multiplayer tic-tac-toe game

What is meant by "multiplayer"

This program does not implement anything network-related. It's multiplayer in the sense that there is a Server (see MainServer) and multiple Clients (see Client), each is an individual Java program that runs independently of the others and communicates with each other via a protocol. However, they all run on the same machine. To simulate true multiplayer experience, players have to remote-connect to the same machine using a third-party tool (e.g. SSH).

How multiplayer is implemented

This program uses a file-based protocol to communicate between the server and clients. The directory containing the game data is structured like this: 

 "server.txt" the main server
 "requests": directory for clients join requests
 | 
 clientID
 : directory for an individual request
 | | "client.txt": the client in this request
 | | "server.txt": the main server in response to this client
 "games": directory for all games
 | 
 gameID
 : directory for an individual game
 | | 
 clientID
 : directory for an individual client in this game
 | | | "client.txt": the client in this game
 | | | "move.txt": the move made by this client
 | | | "server.txt": the game server in response to this client

"server.txt" is the main server's Connection file. The server maintains this Connection to signal that it's running. Clients monitor this connection (see Connection.Monitor) to handle in case the server fails.

A client makes a request to join a game by creating a file at /"requests"/clientID/"client.txt" and maintains its Connection.

The main server monitors the requests directory (see DirectoryMonitor) to detect incoming requests, and monitors the requests connection files to know who's still in the queue vs who has left. When the main server finds 2 requests, it creates a game server and invites the clients to join by writing the game's ID to /"requests"/clientID/"client.txt" (for each client).

Each client monitors the main server's response file (see FileMonitor), and when it gets this message, it joins the game by creating a file at /"games"/gameID/clientID/"client.txt" and maintain its Connection. The game server will monitor this connection to know whether the client is still connected or has abandoned the game.

When the game server receives enough players, it starts the game. Each turn, it writes to each client's /"games"/gameID/clientID/"server.txt" file, telling the game status (who won/lost/tie, or whose turn it is) and the last move made. The clients monitor this file and respond accordingly.

To make a move, the client writes to /"games"/gameID/clientID/"move.txt" the value of its move. The game server monitors this file, updates the game state, then signal the next client to move. And so on.

This is a generic multiplayer protocol that should work for any turn-based game. This program implements a tic-tac-toe game, but with minimal changes it can work with many other games.

As for the game itself

See TicTacToe

  • Constructor Details

  • Method Details

    • main

      public static void main(String[] args)
      Entry point to the program to play the game.

      To play this game, the MainServer program must be running. Start it first and keep it running in the background.

      Parameters:
      args - an optional subcommand (case-insensitive):
      • PvP: start a player vs player game
      • CPU: start a player vs CPU game
      If no subcommand is given, the program repeatedly prompts the user which game to play after each game.

    • play

      public static void play()
      Plays the game.

      Plays multiple games until the user chooses to quit. After each game, the player is prompted whether they want to play against a human or a CPU, or to quit.
